Description: I have been to many Wineries and the Blue Mountain Wine-Tasting experience might be the only one in history where you leave more thirsty than when you came. $40+ for 3 people to get 5 little splashes of wine and some crummy WalMart quality chocolate. Want a little cheese&crackers or to hear the live music? - that's ALL extra cash. What a RIP-OFF.

Description: I thought I was going to the winery not a store in the middle of the local grocery store. The person who did the tasting was knowledgable and great but the atmosphere is not conducive to a wine and cheese pairing class.

Description: Not sure what the Groupon was about, but paying much more than just walking in for sampling, was a rip-off. First, we supposedly paid for $30 worth of wine and cheese pairing for 2, when anyone can just come in and pay $5 per glass, without the $.50 worth of cheese given. There was no tour included in the Groupon. The winery's location and building is beautiful, but the state of dissaray around us was unappealing. There were very few tables and chairs on this beautiful and spacious deck, and you had to make sure you didn't trip on the many patio umbrellas laying everywhere around you, trying to get to a table when it opens up. It is ashame that the owners don't take better care of business.
Name: George O.

Description: The wine and cheese pairing "class" offered was a plate of cheese bits and a woman who had no idea about how to pair them. She didn't offer a new glass for each wine tasting, or even rinse out the glass in between. Not at all worth the money.

Description: The standard wine tasting is 5 per person and includes 5 samples. The group on was 17 for two samplings as well two glasses and a cheese pairing. Personally the cheese wasn't my thing and I have plenty of my own wine glasses. I probably would been just as satisfied with the $5 sampling per person that is offered by the vineyard.

Description: I was disappointed that the Wine and Cheese tasting was not what I expected. Also if you are going to reuse cheese that was previously out at the Sunday's tasting you probably want to keep that to yourself because as a customer that was not what I was expecting. Description: Joe's talk was fun and educational. It was disappointing, though, that standing in a basement constituted the "tour." His wife, who was running the wine tasting, was frazzled -- and she let us know it. It made for an uncomfortable ordeal. She exclaimed that we "must have multiplied downstairs." WHAT? Your poor planning should not be reflected onto the customer WHO IS PAYING YOU to be there. I also didn't like the way the wine tasting was run. I did wine tasting at Mount Hope where much bigger groups are handled effortlessly. MH uses teeny plastic cups and serves one wine at a time to all tasters. The wines are described. We left MH with a case of wine; I bought 3 bottles at BMVC.
